title: Protocols for SARS-CoV-2 infection in primary ocular cells and eye organoids
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Generation of SEAM organoids
Timing: 31–54 days
Passage ESC to seed out colonies for SEAM differentiation, Day -8.
Coat the desired number of wells of a 6-well plate with a 1:80 dilution of Matrigel in DMEM on ice. Use 1–1.5 mL of coating solution in each well and leave the plate to coat for 2 h at 15°C–25°C or at least 1 h in the incubator at 37°C.
Note: Keep the Matrigel solution cold until it is distributed in the well plate to avoid gelling. Agitate the plate side to side and front to back to get and even coating.
Prepare 2 mL mTeSR media per well of a 6-well plate to be seeded and add 0.2 μL/mL of Thiazovivin stock solution.
To passage the feeder-free H9 ESCs, begin by warming 0.5 mM EDTA to 37°C in a dry bath.
Wash one well of a 6-well plate containing 80% confluent feeder-free ESCs with 1 mL of EDTA.
Add 1 mL of EDTA and incubate for 2–3 min.
Carefully aspirate the EDTA and add 1 mL of the prepared mTeSR media containing Thiazovivin. Agitate the plate to lift cells into suspension. Carefully wash the well with the cell suspension while maintaining cell aggregates (avoid breaking into single cells).
Take a 10 μL sample from the cell suspension and mix it with 10 μL Trypan Blue, by vigorous trituration to break up cell clusters.
Count the cells using a hemocytometer.
Transfer a volume corresponding to 5,000 cells/well to be seeded to the prepared mTeSR media. Triturate gently to ensure a homogeneous cell density without breaking the colonies down to single cells.

Aspirate the coating solution and seed the cells in the Matrigel-coated wells. Distribute the aggregates by agitating the plate side to side and front to back.
Incubate the cells for eight days at 37°C, changing the media every 1–3 days. Colonies should be 1–2 mm in diameter (see Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]A) and be well-separated before initiating differentiation.
Critical: The colonies should be sparse with good space between individual colonies >50 colonies/well to avoid colonies merging before zone 3. See Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]B for colonies after 1 week of differentiation.
Note: Stem cells should be karyotyped every 10–15 passages, to test for chromosomal duplications, insertions, deletions, and translocations that can impact the differentiation of the cells.
Initiate SEAM differentiation, Day 0.

Figure 1. SEAM cultures
(A) Human ESC colony before initiating SEAM differentiation, scale bar=1 mm.
(B) SEAM colonies 6 days after initiation of differentiation viewed from the bottom of the well, showing a denser middle zone and cells growing out in concentric circles around the middle zone.
(C) Mature SEAM colonies at 52 days after initiating differentiation, viewed from the top. The middle zone (zone 1, (Z1)) is dense and appear white, with the pigmented cells of zone 2 (Z2) around.
(D) Schematic overview of the four zones of a mature SEAM colony.
(E) SEAM colony stained with DAPI showing the different cell density and cell size of zone 1, 2 and 3, scale bar = 500 μm.
(F) Bright field image of the images in (E), with visually pigmented cells in zone 2. Scale bar = 500 μm.
Warm the SEAM-media to 37°C.
Aspirate half the media in each well and replace it with warm SEAM-media, 1 mL/well.
Initiate SEAM differentiation Day 2.
Warm the SEAM-media to 37°C.

Aspirate half the media in each well and replace it with warm SEAM-media, 1 mL/well.
SEAM maturation Day 4–54.
Aspirate total volume of media in each well every other day and replace it with fresh SEAM-media, 2 mL/well.
Note: Early after the initiation of differentiation, colonies should expand and become more circular, with a denser middle and a more see-through outer zone occupied by larger cells, see Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]B. After approximately 25 days of differentiation, pigmented cells should become visible in zone 2, see Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]C. Further descriptions of the expected SEAM morphology can be found under Expected Outcomes.
Critical: When the culture matures and becomes confluent, extracellular matrix starts forming and some cultures will tend to lift from the plate. Be careful when moving the plate and feeding the cells; avoid agitating the plate to lift cells and collapse the culture (see problem 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.1] under Trouble shooting).
Isolation and culture of adult human ocular cells
Timing: 3–4 weeks
Coat four wells of a 24-well plate per donor tissue type to be cultured with Synthemax-II-SC according to the manufacturer guidelines.
Prepare one 15 mL centrifuge tube for every tissue type to be processed, except retinal pigment epithelium (RPE), with 3 mL 2.5 mg/mL collagenase II, 0.6 μL thiazovivin (40 nM) and 9 μL DNase 1 (1 μU/mL), and heat to 37°C.
Prepare 5 mL trypsin EDTA with 40 nM thiazovivin and 3 μL/mL DNase 1 and heat to 37°C.
Prepare 30 mL TAB 2 media with 10% additional hi-FBS and 40 nM thiazovivin and heat to 37°C.
If receiving a whole globe, sterilize the globe by submersion in a 30% solution of betadine and then rinsing with sterile PBS twice, before proceeding to dissection under sterile conditions. If receiving a cornea rejected for transplant proceed directly to dissection (step 10b).

Isolation of sclera, cornea, and limbus.
Separate the anterior parts of the eye from the posterior part, by making a pars planar circular cut roughly 2 mm posterior to the limbus (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]A).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1687-Fig2.jpg
Figure 2. Schematic of ocular dissection
Step-by-step illustration from when the shells are received until the initial plating and medium change.
(A) Circumferential incision 3–4 mm posterior to the ora serrata.
(B) Separating cornea, limbus, sclera and ciliary body/iris using small scissors, cutting individual pieces 1 mm2, and placing pieces into separate tubes containing collagenase solution.
(C) For the retinal pigment epithelium, remove the retina and add 0.25% trypsin for 45–50 min at 37°C, 5%CO2, 20%O2. Using a sterile nylon paint brush, brush RPE off from the Bruch’s membrane and collect in a conical tube. (D) Separate the Bruch's membrane and choroid from the scleral wall with forceps.
(E) Separate the iris from the ciliary body using forceps, cut into small pieces and place into collagenase solution.
Make a circular cut separating the sclera from the limbus and cornea (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]B Left) and place the scleral tissue in a clean petri dish with sterile PBS to prevent tissue from drying out.
Make a circular cut separating the limbus from the clear tissue of the cornea (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]B middle) and place the limbus and cornea into separate clean petri dishes with sterile PBS to prevent tissue from drying out.
Aspirate the PBS.
Cut the different tissues in to small pieces using a scalpel or a pair of scissors.
Transfer the tissue pieces to the prepared tubes containing collagenase 2 solution. Close The lids loosely to allow gas exchange and incubate at 37°C in the incubator for 2 h, triturating with a p1000 pipette after 1 h of incubation.

Add 300 μL hi-FBS to each tube and triturate with a p1000 pipette to mix.
Pellet the cells by centrifugation at 300 × g for 5 min.
Aspirate the supernatant and resuspend cells in 2 mL TAB2 media with 10% FBS and 40 nM thiazovivin. The cell suspension is divided into four wells of a Synthemax-II-SC coated 24-well plate, 500 μL/well.
Incubate cells at 37°C in the incubator 5% CO2, 20% O2.
Isolation of iris.
Cut the ciliary marginal zone from the choroid at the top of the globe, like how the cornea and limbus were separated from the globe in step 10. Transferer the iris and ciliary marginal zone into a clean petri dish with sterile PBS to prevent tissue from drying.
Separate the iris from the ciliary marginal zone by grabbing the iris with an angled pair of tweezers and the ciliary marginal zone with a pair of blunt tweezers, see Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]E, and pull the tissues from each other.
Place the iris in a clean petri dish.
Cut the tissue into small pieces using a scalpel or a pair of scissors.
Transfer the tissue pieces into the prepared tube containing collagenase 2 solution. Close The lid loosely to allow gas exchange and incubate at 37°C in the incubator for 2 h, triturating with a p1000 pipette after 1 h of incubation.
Add 300 μL hi-FBS to the tube and triturate with a p1000 pipette to mix.
Pellet the cells by centrifugation at 300 × g for 5 min.
Aspirate the supernatant and resuspend cells in 2 mL TAB2 media with 10% FBS and 40 nM thiazovivin. The cell suspension is divided into four wells of a Synthemax-II-SC coated 24-well plate, 500 μL/well.
Incubate cells at 37°C in the incubator 5% CO2, 20% O2.
Isolation of RPE.

Carefully fix the choroid to the sclera by insertion of 3–4 equally spaced 27-gauge needles around the opening of the globe.
Lift out the lens and vitreous. If the retina is not attached to the vitreous, carefully detach the retina from the underlying pigmented cell layer and discard (See problem 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.3] under troubleshooting[href=https://www.wicell.org#troubleshooting] if retina does not detach).
Add approximately 3 mL warm trypsin with 40 nM thiazovivin and 3 μL/mL DNase 1 is carefully, filling to globe to roughly 1 mm below the rim of the choroid-RPE (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]C).
Incubate the globe for 45 min.
Carefully detach the RPE cells from the choroid by gentle agitation with a sterilized brush (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]C). Pigmentation in the trypsin should be clearly noticeable when removing the solution from the eye cup and placing it into media.
Transfer the suspension to a centrifuge tube and add 1/10 of the total volume (roughly 300 μL) hi-FBS to inactivate the trypsin.
Pellet the cells by centrifugation at 300 × g for 5 min.
Aspirate the supernatant and gently resuspend the cells in 2 mL TAB2 media with 10% FBS and 40 nM thiazovivin. The cell suspension is divided into four wells of a Synthemax-II-SC coated 24-well plate, 500 μL/well.
Incubate cells at 37°C in the incubator.
Isolation of choroid.
Gently wash the choroid with sterile PBS to limit RPE contamination.
Peel the choroid from the globe with the blunt tweezers (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]D) and transfer to a clean petri dish.
Cut the tissue in to small pieces using a scalpel or a pair of scissors.
Transfer the tissue pieces to the prepared tube containing collagenase 2 solution. Close the lid loosely to allow gas exchange and incubate at 37°C in the incubator for 2 h, triturating with a p1000 pipette after 1 h of incubation.

Add 300 μL hi-FBS to the tube and triturate with a p1000 pipette to mix.
Pellet the cells by centrifugation at 300 × g for 5 min.
Aspirate the supernatant and resuspend cells in 2 mL TAB2 media with 10% FBS and 40 nM thiazovivin. The cell suspension is divided into four wells of a Synthemax-II-SC coated 24-well plate, 500 μL/well.
Incubate cells at 37°C in the incubator 5% CO2, 20% O2. (See problem 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.5] under troubleshooting[href=https://www.wicell.org#troubleshooting]).
Note: The cells should be left to adhere for at least 48 h without disturbing the plate. After this point the media should be exchanged with fresh TAB2 media every 2–4 days.
Note: When expanding the cells, 10% hi-FBS can be added to increase cell proliferation rate. Once confluent, media should return to lower FBS concentration (2%–5%).
Note: When cells are confluent, they can be used for experiments or be further expanded by lifting with trypsin and replating onto Synthemax-II-SC coated plates. All cell types are passaged as described below.
Expansion of cells.
Aspirate the media and wash cells once with Ca2+- and Mg2+-free PBS.
Add 0.5 mL trypsin to each well to be lifted. Incubate cells with trypsin until they round-up and processes are visibly detaching.
Inactivate the trypsin by adding 0.5 mL 10% hi-FBS in PBS to each well.
Agitate plate to lift cells and transfer cells to a 15 mL centrifuge tube and pellet cells by centrifugation, at 300 × g for 5 min.
Aspirate supernatant and resuspend cells in TAB2 with 10% hi-FBS and 40 nM thiazovivin and replate cells 1:4 in Synthemax-II-SC coated plates.
Incubate cells at 37°C in the incubator 5% CO2, 20% O2.

Note: Cells should be used at low passage numbers (1–4) to avoid morphological and phenotypic changes. Cell identity can be verified with tissue type specific antibody stains, shown in Figure 8[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig8]. RPE cells should have cobblestone morphology and pigmentation. Scleral cells will be elongated, and cornea and limbus cells will look like fibroblast cells with patches for cobblestone morphology.
Infection of SEAM cultures and ocular cells with SARS-CoV-2
Timing: 24 h
This protocol describes how to inoculate SEAM-cultures with SARS-CoV-2 and maintain the cultures during infection. The same approach is applied when inoculating adult donor cells. When inoculating adult donor cells, serum-reduced SEAM media is swapped for TAB2 media, start at step 16.
Prepare 50 mL serum reduced SEAM media.
Mix 47 mL GMEM with 1 mL knockout serum replacement, 0.5 mL GlutaMax, 0.5 mL non-essential amino acids, 0.5 mL penicillin-streptomycin solution, 0.5 mL sodium pyruvate and 19.2 μL β-mercaptoethanol stock (143 mM) to give a final concentration of 55 μM.
Filter the media through a 0.2 μm sterile filter and store at 4°C until use, use within 1 month.
Note: Infections must be performed in media with maximum 2% serum. For infection of adult donor cells, infections should be carried out in TAB2-media. TAB2-media has 2% serum as standard and can be used directly.
Warm the serum-reduced SEAM-media to 37°C in a dry bath.
In the biosafety cabinet, prepare virus inoculum by diluting SARS-CoV-2 virus stock to 1 M.O.I. in 500 μL SEAM-media per 6-well to be infected.
In the biosafety cabinet, aspirate the media from the SEAM culture and replace with the prepared SARS-CoV-2 inoculum. In control wells, replace the media with serum reduced SEAM media without SARS-CoV-2.

Place the SEAM-culture plate in the incubator in a humidified atmosphere at 37°C, 5% CO2, 20% O2 for one hour and gently rock the plate every ten minutes to allow for even distribution of virus inoculum across the SEAM cultures.
After one hour, move the plate back to the biosafety cabinet. Aspirate the inoculum and replace with 2 mL serum-reduced SEAM-media. Incubate the plate at 37°C until the experimental endpoint.
Proceed to qPCR, single-cell RNA sequencing (scRNAseq), Plaque assay, or immunohistochemistry protocol.
Note: In all cases except for the plaque assay, quantification of infection was done 24 h post infection. For the plaque assay samples were taken at 12 h, 24 h, 36 h, 48 h and 72 h post infection, see Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]A.
Critical: All work with SARS-CoV-2 virus must be carried out in a biosafety level 3 facility. When handling the virus, follow all CDC and institutionally approved guidelines. All waste material must be inactivated in an approved disinfectant and autoclaved before discarding.
Immunohistochemistry
Timing: 51 h
This protocol describes how to stain infected cells in 12-well plates, to evaluate infection and expression of the SARS-CoV-2 entry factor ACE2. The protocol can be used for cell type identifying markers and in SEAM cultures as well.
Fix cells with 4% PFA.
Aspirate the media from the infected cells and control cells.
Wash cells 3 times with 1 mL/well PBS.
Remove PBS and add 1 mL of ice cold 4% PFA in PBS to each well. Seal the plate with parafilm and fix for a sufficient amount of time, following a protocol approved by your institution to ensure that the virus is completely inactivated, for our institution this is 24 h, at 4°C.
Aspirate the PFA solution and wash the cells 3 times with 1 mL/well PBS.

Stain the cells with mouse anti-SARS-CoV-2-S and rabbit anti-ACE2.
Block for unspecific antibody binding.
Prepare blocking buffer, (See materials and equipment[href=https://www.wicell.org#materials-and-equipment] section).
Aspirate PBS and add 0.5 mL blocking buffer to each well. Leave cells to block for 1 h on a bench rocker at 15°C–25°C.
Add primary antibodies.
Prepare staining buffer.
Prepare dilutions of primary antibodies in staining buffer, 0.25 mL/well; mouse anti-SARS-CoV-2 (1:100), rabbit anti-ACE2 (1:100).
Aspirate blocking buffer and incubate cells with primary antibodies on bench rocker at 4°C 12–18 h.
Wash and add secondary antibodies.
Aspirate the buffer and wash the cell by adding 0.25 mL/well fresh staining buffer and incubate on bench rocker for 5 min at 15°C–25°C. Repeat for a total of 3 washes.
Prepare secondary antibodies diluted in staining buffer, 0.25 mL/well, goat-anti-mouse Alexa Fluor-488 (1.1000) and goat-anti-rabbit Alexa Fluor-647 (1:500), lastly add the nuclear stain, DAPI (1:1000).
After the last wash, aspirate the buffer and add 0.25 mL staining buffer with secondary antibody stains to each well. Incubate for 1 h on bench rocker at 15°C–25°C. Protect the plate from light to avoid bleaching of the fluorophores from this step onwards.
Aspirate the buffer and wash 3 × 5 min with PBS.
After the final wash step, add PBS to cover cells. If proceeding directly to imaging, add minimal volume of PBS to cover cells for improved contrast in bright field images.
Optional: For better, high-resolution imaging, SEAM cultures, and cells intended for immunohistochemical investigation, can be grown on glass bottom plates or cover slips.
Pause point: Stained cells can be stored in sealed plates at 4°C for up to two months. When storing cells, add PBS to prevent the plate from drying and 0.1% Na-azide to prevent bacterial growth.
Measuring infection in by qPCR
Timing: 5.5 h

This protocol describes how to quantify expression levels of SARS-CoV-2 entry factors ACE2 and TMPRSS2 and SARS-CoV-2 infection in adult donor ocular cells. This analysis is performed on fully confluent cells grown in 24-well plates and infected with 1 M.O.I. of SARS-CoV-2 24 h prior to starting this step of the protocol. The same protocol can be used for quantification of infection in SEAM cultures, adjusting the volumes to accommodate the larger well format in the lysis step.
RNA extraction using TRIzol, adapted from Pub. No. 0001271 B.0.
Aspirate cell media and wash 3 times with 0.5 mL PBS.
Lyse cells by adding 500 μL TRIzol reagent (Invitrogen) to each well and triturate the cells vigorously to lyse all cells before transferring the cell lysate to a clean 1.5 mL tube.
Incubate for 5 min at 15°C–25°C.
Pause point: Samples can be stored at −80°C for at least 1 year.
Add 100 μL chloroform to each tube, cap the tube thoroughly, and vortex the samples for 30 s.
Incubate samples for 5 min at 15°C–25°C.
Precipitate the organic phase by centrifugating at >12,000 × g for 15 min.
Transfer the aqueous phase (the top phase) to a new tube. Be careful to not contaminate the aqueous phase with material from the organic phase.
Add 5 μL RNase-free glycogen to the sample and mix by inverting ten times.
Add 250 μL isopropanol, mix by inverting ten times and incubate for 10 min on ice.
Precipitate the RNA by centrifugating at > 12,000 × g for 10 min at 4°C.
Discard the supernatant.
Dissolve the pellet in 75% ethanol and re-pellet by centrifugating 12,000 × g for 5 min at 4°C.
Discard the supernatant and leave the tube open to dry the pellet.
Resuspend the dry pellet in 20 μL RNase-free water.

Remove DNA from sample with DNA-free DNA removal kit (Invitrogen) following the protocol of the manufacturer (Cat. No. AM1906 (ThermoFisher)).
Add 2 μL 10× DNase Buffer and 1 μL DNase I to each sample.
Incubate the samples at 37°C for 30 min.
Add 2.5 μL DNase Inactivating reagent to each sample and incubate for 2 min mixing every 30 s.
Spin for 1.5 min at 12,000 × g and transfer supernatant to a clean tube.
Determine RNA concentration on NanoDrop (Thermo Scientific) or by using a bioanalyzer (Agilent).
Reverse transcribe RNA to cDNA using Superscript II. (Cat. No: 18064-022 (Invitrogen)).
Based on the results from the NanoDrop find the samples with the lowest concentration of RNA. From this sample calculate the amount of RNA in 6 μL of the sample. Based on this amount calculate the volume of RNA to take from additional samples so the amount of RNA is equivalent.
Take the desired volumes of each RNA sample and transfer to clean PCR tubes.
Adjust the volume of all samples to 12 μL with RNase-free water.
Add 1 μL oligo d(T)12-18 to each sample.
Add 1 μL dNTP Mix to each sample.
Incubate the samples for 5 min at 65°C, before snap cooling on ice.
Spin the samples shortly to collect evaporation from the cap.
Prepare a Master Mix of 4 μL 5× first stand buffer, 2 μL 0.1 M DTT and 1 μL RNaseOUT per sample.
Add 6 μL Master Mix to each sample and mix gently by triturating.
Incubate 2 min at 15°C–25°C.
Add 1 μL SuperScript II to each sample and incubate samples at 42°C for 50 min.
Stop the reaction by incubating at 70°C for 15 min.
Pause point: cDNA samples are stable and can be stored at −20°C for up to 1 year.

qPCR using KAPA SYBR green fast qPCR Master Mix kit, protocol adapted from manufacturer’s guidelines: (Cat. No. KK4601 (Merck)). Expected outcome for quantification of subgenomic N transcript normalized to tubulin from different ocular cells can be seen in Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]B.
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1687-Fig3.jpg
Figure 3. SARS-CoV-2 infection in SEAM and ocular cells
(A) Virus growth in SEAM cultures shown as plaque-forming units per milliliter of supernatant at the time points indicated. Error bars show SD (n = 3).
(B) qRT-PCR for SARS-CoV-2 subgenomic N transcript on total RNA extracted from ocular tissues infected with SARS-CoV-2. Error bars = SEM. Originally published in (Eriksen et al., 2021).
Prepare primer mixes for each of the genes of interest (SARS-CoV-2, ACE-2, TMPRSS2 and bTubulin) by mixing forward and reverse primers 1:1. For primer sequences see key resources table[href=https://www.wicell.org#key-resources-table].
In a 384-well plate, pipette out 1 μL of the cDNA samples in triplicate so that there are 3 replicates for every sample and primer set.
Add 1 μL of the appropriate primer mix in each well.
Add 8 μL PCR grade water to each sample.
Add 10 μL KAPA SYBR fast qPCR 2× into each sample and mix gently by pipetting up and down.
Seal the plate with a clean adhesive strip and spin the plate for 2 min at 1,000 × g.
Perform PCR reaction as described in the table below.

Single-cell RNA sequencing
Timing: 10 h +
This step describes how to dissociate SEAM cultures into a single cell suspension ready to be processed for single-cell RNA sequencing.
Dissociate SEAM culture to form a single cell suspension.

Prepare collagenase II stock solution. Weigh out 25 mg of collagenase II in a 15 mL centrifuge tube. Dissolve the enzyme in 5 mL Ca2+- and Mg2+-free PBS and filter the solution through a 0.2 μm filter in sterile conditions.
Note: The collagenase stock solution should be stored at 4°C and used within 1 month.
Prepare digestion buffer. For every 1 well of a 6-well plate to be dissociated, mix 1 mL of the collagenase II stock solution, 993.6 μL Ca2+- and Mg2+-free PBS 0.4 μL thiazovivin (to give a final concentration of 40 nM) and 6 μL DNase I.
Prepare preservation media. Mix 5 mL DMEM:F12 with 1 μL thiazovivin (to give a final concentration of 40 nM), 0.2 μL BSA (from 25% stock), and 15 μL DNase I.
Aspirate the media from the well and wash the cells with Ca2+- and Mg2+-free PBS.
Add 2 mL digestion buffer to the well and incubate the place at 37°C for 30 min.
Triturate the cells using a p1000 pipette, and incubate for an additional 30 min at 37°C.
Optional: If cells are not dissociating and large clumps are visible, add 0.5 mL fresh digestion buffer and incubate for an additional 30 min.
Triturate using a p1000 pipette the cell to break clumps down to single cells, transfer the cell suspension to a 15 mL centrifuge tube, and pellet the cells by spinning at 300 × g for 5 min.
Aspirate the supernatant and resuspend the pellet in 2 mL preservation media and filter the suspension through a 40 μm cell strainer.
Count the cells and viability using a hemocytometer and Trypan Blue.
Critical: Only if there is >10,000 cells and the viability is >80% continue to single-cell library preparation.

Preparation of single-cell library according to the manufacturer’s instructions (Cat. No: CG000331 Rev C, 10 Genomics). Data analysis can be performed in R using the Seurat package (Stuart et al., 2019[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib8]). A code workflow is available on NCBI GEO GSE165477.
Critical: The subgenomic RNAs of SARS-CoV-2 all have unique 5′ ends but share the same 3′ end. Hence, it is crucial to use a library prep kit that is based on 5′ capture of transcripts such as Chromium Next GEM Single Cell 5′ Kit v2 (10×, cat no. RN-10000265) in order to be able to distinguish between viral gene transcripts (Cohen et al., 2021[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib2]).
Note: The 10× protocol provides several possible pause points so that library preparation can be split up over several days if needed.
Plaque assay
Timing: 4 days
Plaque assays are performed to show that a viral infection is productive and that there is true replication of the virus in the infected cells. Here we describe how to perform a plaque assay on infected SEAM cultures to show productive infection in the eye organoids; however, plaque assays can be carried out on any cell type grown and infected in vitro. The plaque assay protocol is also used to titer the concentration of infectious virus used for infection experiments.
Seed Vero E6 cells at 400,000 cells/well in a 12 well plate and incubate cells at 37°C 5% CO2 12–18 h.
From the infected SEAM cultures, take 1 mL of the used media from each well and transfer to a clean 1.5 mL tube, Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]A.
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1687-Fig4.jpg
Figure 4. Schematic of the workflow of a plaque assay
(A) A sample of the cell media from infected cells is collected. Repeat the sample collection at different time points.
(B) Spin sample to pellet dead cells and debris.

(C) Make dilution series of media sample and add samples to Vero E6 cells in culture.
(D) Add overlay media and incubate for 2–3 days.
(E) Fix plate and stain with crystal violet, infected colonies will be visible as white dots.
Spin the samples for 5 min at 300 × g to pellet any cells and transfer the supernatant to a clean 1.5 mL tube, Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]B.
Make a logarithmic dilution series of the conditioned media samples.
To make a 10-1X sample, take 100 μL conditioned media and dilute it with 900 μL Modified DMEM, Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]C.
To make a 10-2X sample, take 100 μL of the 10-1X sample and dilute it with 900 μL Modified DMEM.
Continue as described above until a dilution of 10-6.
Inoculate the Vero E6 using conditioned media samples.
Aspirate the media and replace with 900 μL modified DMEM.
Add 100 μL diluted infected sample media in each well.
Allow virus adsorption by incubating for 1 h at 37°C 5% CO2, agitating the plate every 10 min.
Add solid overlay.
Aspirate the inoculation media.
Add 1 mL/well overlay media, Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]D.
Incubate for 48–60 h at 37°C 5% CO2.
Note: Make overlay media with oxoid agar fresh every time.
Fix the plates by adding 1 mL/well 4% PFA and incubate for a sufficient amount of time to ensure complete inactivation of infectious virus approved by your institution.
Remove the fixative and stain each well by adding 1 mL/well crystal violet solution in 20% ethanol and incubate for 15 min at 15°C–25°C.
Aspirate the staining solution and determine viral titers (PFU/mL) by counting white colonies of dead cells in each sample, Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]E (see problem 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.9] under troubleshooting[href=https://www.wicell.org#troubleshooting]).
